data.title: Chennakesava Temple Guide Offers Serenity To Visitors In 2024
data.meta_description: Step into the captivating realm of Chennakesava Temple where olden times resonate with structural magnificence as you unveil the mysteries enshrouding.
data.text:
Enveloped by the placid Somanathapura village lies the mesmerizing Chennakesava Temple, which illustrates India’s unmatched artistic work and traditional depth. This enchanting 13th-century structure is a testament to the artistry practised by the Hoysalas. Its celestial beauty dedicated to Lord Vishnu mesmerizes people globally, such as with its elaborate carvings and sculptures that have almost turned back time. It is guaranteed to be remembered by you forever due to its loveable history, attractive structure, and harmonious environment.

The Architectural Grandeur Of Chennakesava Temple

Image Credit: Dineshkannambadi for wikimedia commons

Somanatha Dandanayaka, the general of Hoysala King Narasimha III, commissioned Chennakesava Temple in 1268 CE. The town, named after its patron, Somanathapura, soon became a significant cultural and spiritual hub.

It is worth noting that this temple was made of soapstone, which had to be brought from other faraway places for its astounding architectural display. The people who made drawings or carved out images of deities in these temples must have been great masters.

Places To Visit Nearby Chennakesava Temple

There are other amazing sites here besides the temple; hence, tourists can fully engage in the culture by visiting those places together.

1. Halebidu – Hoysaleshwara Temple

Image Source: Pexels

A must-visit destination just a short drive from Somanathapura is Halebidu, a former capital of the Hoysala Empire. It is also home to the main attraction here, Hoysaleshwara temple, which has complex carvings, making it more beautiful. There are many scenes on the temple’s walls, with some depicting the epics of Ramayana while others of Mahabharata. Thus, numerous Hindu deities dotted around its façade add colour to all these illustrations. Kedareswara Temple is another architectural masterpiece in this region renowned for its Chalukyan style and beautiful sculptures.

Location: Halebeedu, Karnataka 573121

Timings: 6:30 AM to 6:30 PM

2. Mysore Palace

Image Source: Pexels

Mysore is a grand place to visit, not far from Somanathapura. It is the proud home of the Mysore Palace, a beautiful manifestation of Indo-Saracenic architecture, something you should probably see. It was constructed in 1897 AD during this epoch, proving the majesty, wealth and riches associated with the Wodeyar Dynasty. The construction of this castle includes various sections, each displaying distinctly different architectural techniques signifying the interweaving of multiple cultures, such as Hinduism and Islam. However, some gothic touches can be found here and there on the same premise.

Location: Agrahara, Chamrajpura, Mysuru, Karnataka 570004

Timings: 10 AM to 5:30 PM

Suggested Read: Hoysaleswara Temple

3. Brindavan Gardens

Image Credit: Joe Ravi for wikimedia commons

Mysore is also home to the Brindavan Gardens, which no visitor should miss. These beautifully landscaped terraces with musical fountains offer peaceful leisure and meditation conditions. Spanning across 150 acres, this garden also provides ideal picnic sites and is preferred by those who like taking evening walks. Musical fountains, coordinated with music, offer exciting moments in this garden.

Location: CHCF+X2V, Krishnarajasagara, Karnataka 571607

Timings: 9 AM to 11 PM

4. Hoysala Emblem

Image Source:Facebook

Various temples and monuments have the Hoysala Emblem, symbolising the Hoysala dynasty in the area. This emblem, which shows the strength and power of Hoysala rulers through a lioness head mixed with elephant skin on its back, represents them as strong people who should win wars at all costs. Thus, those keen on knowing more about this locality should not fail to visit it.

Location: Yagachi Bridge, Belur, Karnataka 573115

Timings: Open 24 hours

Suggested Read: Airports In Karnataka

5. Chamundi Hills – Shri Chamundeshwari Temple

Image Source: Facebook

Another option for you to enjoy this area’s incredible beauty is the Chamundi Hills, which lie not far from Mysore town. On one hill, there is an ancient but tranquil sanctum where Goddess Chamundeshwari sits looking over Mysore city and beyond. This sanctum suspended up there, offers a complete panorama of the city and its environs from the topmost point of this hill. Built-in such a way that it can deceive the eyes and bring a memorable impression, the temple showcases architectural wonder that amazes all who see it. With its detailed sculptures and intricate metal carvings, among other things found, there will be no doubts remaining about how talented ancient Indian artists were.

Location: Shri Chamundeshwari Temple Road, Chamundi Hill, Mysuru, Karnataka 570010

Timings: 7:30 AM to 9:00 PM

Best Time To Visit

Image Credit: Dineshkannambadi for wikimedia commons

You should plan your visit to Chennakeshava temple between October and March because it experiences the best weather conditions. During daylight hours, temperatures often fall slightly below 32 degrees Celsius, while evening temperatures drop to just over 20 degrees Celsius. Unlike in summer, there aren’t many people around, allowing visitors to admire its beauty without disturbance.

If you are lucky, you might see some local festivals in Karnataka, like Kambala (a traditional buffalo race) in January and Makar Sankranti. This harvest festival is also celebrated in January. Through these festivals, the vibrant atmosphere that characterizes the state is accentuated, offering a preview of their culture.

Suggested Read: Historical Places In Karnataka

How To Reach Chennakesava Temple

Image Credit: Akhila Srikanta Rao for wikimedia commons

By Air: The Bangalore airport is the closest airport to Somanathapura, at around 130 km.

By Train: Chikmagalur is the nearest railway station to Somanathapura, approximately 22 km away. Alternatively, Hassan train station is just 32 km away.

By Road: On its eastern side at around 38 kilometres, Hassan townhouses Somanathapura. There are regular buses and taxis from Hassan to this temple town. You could also take a bus or hire a cab from Bangalore, about 130 km north-west of Somanathapura.

The temple is located in the small village of Somanathapura, right by the Kaveri River. Towards the east is its central gate, within tall stone-fostered walls. Upon arrival at Somanathapura, walking straight towards the temple is possible because it stands out as one of the most noticeable places within the settlement. It operates from 8:30 a.m. through 5:30 p.m.

Now that you have a list of things to remember for your next vacation to enjoy at Chennakesava Temple, make sure you plan your trip to Karnataka to these fabulous spots accompanied by your loved ones. This experience will be more rewarding as you experience all the fun with them. Don’t miss out on these opportunities; book your tickets now!

Frequently Asked Questions About Chennakesava Temple

How long does it take to see all the places near Chennakesava temple?

To truly appreciate everything that’s around Chennakesava Temple it’s worth spending at least 2-3 days here. This way you can take it easy during your trip visiting temples, museums as well and some markets while embracing your lifestyle.

When would be the perfect time to come to Chennakesava temple?

Chennakesava temple is best visited between November and February as the weather conditions during these months are comfortable and perfect for outdoor events.

What are the best-loved traditional foods of Somanathapura?

In Somanathapura, Malnad cuisine is popular, with Kesuvina Gantu, Sihi Kaayi Kabadu and Bennekaayi Balaka among others.

What deities can be found at the temple?

Keshava, Janardhana and Venugopala are the principal deities at the temple representing different forms of Lord Vishnu. The chief idol of Keshava is no more as the invaders destroyed it.

How do people get to the Chennakesava Temple?

Chennakesava Temple is about 35 km east of Mysore city. Going there, one can easily reach Somanathapura by taxi or bus.
